passages.text: Israel | InsuranceHarel
Unparalleled Optionality

In our view, Harel's 1H 2025 results continue the industry- wide trend of surprisingly high investment returns. Combined with the already high level of surplus assets in the holding company, and an accounting- driven improvement in interest rate sensitivity, this leads us to conclude that Harel's management currently have unusually few binding constraints.

Underlying Underwriting Ahead - As has been the case for the rest of the Israeli insurance sector, Harel reported impressive 1H 2025 earnings today. As the Contract Service Margin (CSM) and Risk Adjustment (RA) releases comprise \(72\%\) and \(14\%\) of the underwriting profit, and \(40\%\) and \(8\%\) of the pretax comprehensive income, respectively, we view these as the most important line items. In this regard, the CSM release was \(+5.9\%\) higher than we expected and the RA release was \(+12.8\%\) higher. Moreover, the Non- Life business continues to improve its margins, with the Insurance Service Result (ISR) being \(+45.9\%\) ahead. However, this underlying improvement was offset by Health, where underwriting profits were \(- 15.7\%\) lower than we expected, so that the group ISR was only \(+0.4\%\) ahead. This miss in Health was prompted by higher frequency and severity of medication claims as well as our model underestimating the amortisation of acquisition costs.

Comprehensively Ahead - Beyond underwriting, although variances in investment returns are inherently nonrecurring, Insurance Net Investment & Finance income was a remarkable NIS 424m higher than modelled (similar to peers), driving Insurance Comprehensive Income (pretax) NIS 389m higher \((+30.0\%)\) . Outside of Insurance, Comprehensive Income missed by \(- 8.8\%\) in Credit and \(- 6.3\%\) in Investment Contracts, while Provident beat by \(+4.2\%\) , Financial Services by \(+8.2\%\) , and Pension by \(+15.4\%\) .

Spending the Excess - Looking ahead, one of the key questions will be how management choose to deploy their excess cash. Currently, the holding company has a remarkable net surplus of NIS 1,547m, largely invested in liquid assets, with only NIS 32m in nontradeable debt. One potential use of this is the acquisition of a stake in CAL, where management had hoped to own a \(49\%\) share of the Joint Venture that is seeking to buy Discount Bank's \(72\%\) stake. As regulatory approvals could take a year, we believe that deploying the remaining surplus ought to be a key topic for the next plan.

Upstreaming the Capital - In terms of capital, although there is not a strategic target for the insurance subsidiary's solvency II ratio, we would suggest a range of \(150\% - 170\%\) , in line with peers. With that minimum, Harel's \(187\%\) (or \(159\%\) excluding transitional) appears adequate, meaning that capital generated can be upstreamed to the holding company and used for strategic acquisitions (or buybacks). Hopefully, Harel will consider adopting cash remittance discounts (as Phoenix Financial has) to allow investors to track dividend flows.

A Question of Sensitivity - One final outstanding question concerns interest rate sensitivity. Historically, falling yields were a highly material headwind, with a \(- 1\%\) fall costing NIS - 1,272m (FY24 exposures), while a \(+1\%\) uplift creates a NIS 19m gain. Given that many investors (us and Harel included) believe that cuts are likely, Harel would be incentivised to hedge this. However, the revaluation of liabilities under IFRS 17 means that Harel is overhedged, such that a \(- 1\%\) cut drives a NIS 357 gain, whereas a \(+1\%\) uplift creates a NIS - 400m loss. This creates a dilemma, as the optimal decision (for profits) might be to extend the overexposure to government bonds, whereas reducing the exposure might eliminate the interest rate sensitivity (reducing risk).

HarelHarel is a leading conglomerate insurer in the Israeli insurance market, with business across most insurance lines and financial services. The group is Israel's dominant health insurer due to their long- standing relationships with Israel's Health Maintenance Organisations (HMOs).

We derive our 12- month price target from a multistage residual income valuation model. Upside risks include higher premium growth, reduced debt leverage, and higher levels of capital returns. Downside risks include higher inflation in Israel, lower premium growth, and natural catastrophes.

In terms of valuation methodology, we settle on a Gordon growth framework using ROTE and cost of equity on a 2027E basis, as well as the discounted value of dividend payments. The two primary risks for Israeli banks are 1) any factor that impacts management's ability to execute on efficiency improvement (primarily headcount and digital) and 2) a downturn in the domestic economy. In terms of our constructive ratings, any geopolitical disruption could lead investors to demand greater compensation per unit of risk and drive cost of equity higher for these names, dampening the outlook even in the absence of earnings changes.

We derive our 12- month price target from a multi- stage, residual income valuation model. Upside risks include higher growth, and downside risks include natural catastrophes or mark- to- market losses.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7of MAR)

Jefferies Fiacial Group Inc., its affiliates or subsidiaries is acting as a manager or co- manager in the underwriting or placement of securities for Phoenix Financial Ltd or one of its affiliates.

- Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of 15% or more within a 12-month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus 15% or minus 10% within a 12-month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus 10% or less within a 12-month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10 is 20\%\) or more within a 12-month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus 20% within a 12-month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) 10, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus 20% or less within a 12-month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.

NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company. Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with the series engeement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations. Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise PicksJefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
